document_title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight
summary_full: This study introduces a 3D-printed Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) designed for high-throughput phenotypic assays of Caenorhabditis elegans, suitable for both Earth-based research and spaceflight applications. The CIP integrates with a smartphone camera, eliminating the need for external optics and mechanical focusing, thus simplifying its design and operation. It is compact, USB-powered, and can be housed in incubators for temperature control, making it plug-and-play and suitable for parallel operation. The platform demonstrates compatibility with various C. elegans substrates, including agar plates, liquid droplets, and microfluidic chips. Validation through behavioral and thrashing assays shows phenotypic readouts consistent with literature data. A pilot study with mutants (unc-32 and unc-79) successfully distinguished their distinct phenotypes, highlighting the CIP's utility for mutant characterization. The authors emphasize the CIP's suitability for spaceflight due to its small size, low weight, and ease of use, addressing limitations of current microscopy systems on the International Space Station.
key_findings: Developed a 3D-printed Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) for C. elegans phenotyping, integrating with smartphone cameras.
CIP is compact, low-power (USB), requires no external optics or mechanical focusing, and supports parallel operation.
Demonstrated compatibility with agar plates, liquid droplets, and microfluidic chips for C. elegans assays.
Validated system performance with behavioral and thrashing assays, showing results consistent with literature.
Successfully distinguished phenotypes of C. elegans mutants (unc-32 and unc-79) using the CIP.
CIP is proposed as a suitable, user-friendly, and spaceflight-amenable tool for C. elegans research.
future_research_fields: Integration of higher magnification optics for deeper phenotyping (organ-level information).
Adaptation of the 3D-printed station for other low-cost cameras and integration with Raspberry Pi.
Incorporation of hardware for studying animal responses to stimuli (light, temperature, electric fields).
Development of custom apps for real-time image analysis, metadata storage, and data visualization using AI.
Full ISS certification for flammability, materials, off-gassing, and electromagnetic interference.

conclusions: The Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) is a versatile, low-cost, and small-footprint tool for C. elegans phenotyping, suitable for both research and educational settings on Earth. Its design and demonstrated capabilities make it a promising candidate for future space biology research on the ISS, addressing current limitations in hardware, crew time, and payload constraints. Further improvements and ISS certification are needed for spaceflight deployment.
impact_statement: This compact and versatile imaging platform simplifies C. elegans phenotypic analysis, making it more accessible for research on Earth and enabling crucial biological studies in the constrained environment of spaceflight.
